discussion.content: Network Admin is not using a a console cable in this situation he is going to go to the router interface page over a internet secure connection as out of bound method is actually a remote access.

Console port is used to connect a computer directly to a router or switch and manage the router or switch since there is no display device for a router or switch . ... A special type of cable, known as roll over cable is used to connect the Serial/COM port of the computer to the router or switch console port.

choices.B: Walk a user through troubleshooting the connection
choices.D: Hire a contractor to go on-site
choices.A: Use a modem to console into the router

questions.question_text: A network technician notices the site-to-site VPN and Internet connection have not come back up at a branch office after a recent power outage. Which of the following is an out-of-band method the technician would MOST likely utilize to check the branch office's router status?

comments.content: Yea but video camera doesn't prevent it. I get what you're saying about obtaining the card but the answer given is right

discussion.content:
what is the smartcard is maliciously obtained from the possession of an authorised user?
meaning, if an unauthorised person by chance is in the procession of the smart card? the only option to check who actually gained an entrance with the specific smart card is with the surveillance/video camera. it is a possibility.
its the only one that would stop access on the spot. the others would be delayed.
No one even questioned this? Smart card would not prevent

comments.content: Why not? Only authorized person would have the smart reader's card. I thought thats the best answer
prevents nothing? what about non-employees who dont have the card?

Where I work, every single desk has a smartcard reader and anyone can hop on that desk and log in with their own card (and of course their own credentials). I'm with boydmwanza, a smartcard reader prevents nothing.

Correct answer is D. Smart card reader

I stand corrected. Smart cards fall under Meyer's section covering physical security (prevention and control) and the definition given does help my see the perspective of its use for prevention.

"smart card - Device (such as a credit card, USB key, etc.) that you insert into you PC in lieu of entering a password."
-Mike Meyers, Network+ Certification Exam N10-006, pg. 676, 856)

In this scenario, the smart card reader would presumably be at the door to enter the datacenter and those authorized to enter would be (via their smart card) on the access control list.

questions.question_text: Which of the following physical security devices is used to prevent unauthorized access into a datacenter?

discussion.content: YES, it is social engineering, more precisely it is VISHING ----- the fraudulent practice of making phone calls or leaving voice messages purporting to be from reputable companies in order to induce individuals to reveal personal information, such as bank details and credit card numbers.
Social Engineering has to do with disguise, fraud, pretence, etc and in this case, the caller was actually disguising as a staff or a colleague to collect those needed information.

As defined in my Security+ SY0-501 CompTIA Student Study Guide:
Social Engineering:
Social engineering attacks can come in a variety of methods; in person, through email, or over the phone.
I think the answer is D because hi side "receive call from internal number"

comments.content: Nope numbers can be spoofed easily, recently a small business owner got scammed out of all her company finances by someone who spoofed Barclays number as apparently they are the only bank that haven't prevented this yet.
I think Social Engineering is right. The person behind the number was acting like an insider threat when he's not. In this case he was acting like an employee

discussion.content: Wouldn't this be an insider threat? Social engineering would be someone else acting as an employee, but the question clearly states that the number was from the company...

questions.question_text: A few weeks after starting a new position, Joe, a junior network administrator, receives a call from an internal number asking for his username and password to update some records. Joe realizes this may be a type of attack on the network, since he has full access to network resources. Which of the following attacks is described?

A technician is sent to troubleshoot a faulty network connection. The technician tests the cable, and data passes through successfully. No changes were made in the environment, however, when a network device is connected to the switch using the cable, the switchport will not light up. Which of the following should the technician attempt NEXT?

discussion.content: The tricky part about the question is "The" cable. I referring to a specific cable port.

comments.content: It was verified the cable was good, that was a troubleshooting to confirm the cable was good. The step was to moved the cable to a diff port on the switch to confirm if the port was faulty.

They asked the "next" step in the process. So the cable is working, nothing was changed to the environment, but the port is not lighting up. Check to see if it works on another port would be the next step in the process. Changing the switch would come after that.

Because as a tech you usually want to start with the most obvious solutions first before you move on to more complex and time consuming solutions. In this case it made sense to try another port FIRST before he did anything drastic like change the whole switch

discussion.content: Okay so I'm not debating it being B but I need to know why it can't be D. Because the question said that they verified data could pass through the cable but that doesn't say much about the switch being fully operational.

questions.question_text: A technician has been assigned to capture packets on a specific switchport. Which of the following switch features MUST be used to accomplish this?

discussion.content: Port mirroring is a method of copying and sending network packets transmitted as input from a port to another port of a monitoring computer/switch/device.
